Bond was about the same size as John Wayne--6' 3", 220 pounds--but did NOT wear elevator shoes in his later years, as did Wayne. This short mentions 30 of Bond's films by name, and states that 1935 was his biggest year, when he appeared in 30 flicks! This "bonus feature" also notes that he (unlike Wayne) had a doctor's note to avoid fighting in WWII--Bond was 4F because of epilepsy.

Here I go again, reviewing a generic western in my generic, western-reviewing way.Rio Bravo is another example of solid John Wayne western entertainment. It's basically good clean fun, with the badguys on one side wanting to spring one of their own from jail, and the Duke and a couple of sidekicks trying to stop them.What makes this film stand out as memorable is essentially the characters. Dean Martin is great as the main deputy recovering from a drunken spell and finding his knack for firing a gun again. Ricky Nelson has a smaller role as a determined young kid, and Walter Brennan is simply wonderful as the crotchety old man. The Duke is naturally a powerful presence on screen.These characters provide the entertainment, and there's plenty of action to help the film along the way as well. However, at two and a quarter hours, it is a little too long. There is a scene in the jail where Martin and Nelson show off their fine singing voices which is unnecessary to the plot. Similarly, the romance subplot between the Duke and Angie Dickenson doesn't exactly help the story along either. But then what kind of a western would this be without romance? A shorter one, sure, but also a lesser one. So basically it's as good as it can be, but with that quality also comes length. It seems to me as though that's the way it has to be.It's a good romp, definitely worth seeing once and enjoyed. Don't expect a masterpiece and you'll leave with a smile on your face. **** / *****

reviews.review_title: Can't get any better than this!
reviews.content: I have read many reviews of Rio Bravo,some get it right,some don't. The running time is long,pacing perfect,but the movie is typical Hawks.It is actually a character study,it may be viewed by many as corny and clichéd,but I'm a Hawks and Wayne fan,and as such,I love this picture.Great score,the cinematography revels in brownish hues,giving it a flavor of the southwest It really is about friendship and loyalty,right and wrong.It is also a series of scenes apart from one another.My favorite is the bar scene in the beginning.Please watch the supporting cast,they are brilliant,especially Dean Martin and Walter Brennan.A classic.

Angie Dickinson may get all the best lines in Rio Bravo, but John Wayne is the one that she surrenders to in the end. She is the prototypical Hawksian woman; witty, sharp as a knife, wielding her sexuality with provocation. Her drawl is the antithesis of Hawks' earlier screwballs and their mile-a-minute dialogue, overlapping and building to a comedic climax. When Feathers sashays and suggests a strip-search, and when she dangles her arms around his neck and pulls him in for a second kiss after a lacklustre first effort, you'll see a rare glimpse of a John Wayne character flustered.By slowing it all down, Hawks was able to build his scenes from the ground up, filling them to the brim with tension. See the iconic opening, a wordless 5 minute sequence that renders a simple bar scuffle into an operatic showdown. Dude enters from the back door a sweaty outsider, lurking in the shadows and pacing back and forth, eyes darting towards the drink. The camera doesn't rush him; you can see why Kurosawa drew inspiration from the American western, where Mifune got his steady, measured shuffle from. Dean Martin, the disgraced star, crawls to the ground for a coin, only to usher in the entrance of the town sheriff, Wayne towering over his failed protégé. No more than a minute later, they are holding a murderer at gunpoint together.It was filmed at the Old Tucson studio backlot, so there are no expansive vistas of the west ala John Ford. The daytime exterior shots do little to hide the appearance of a set, reflecting a campy western aesthetic (see the bickering over dynamite throwing in the climax), but the interiors of the homesteads and taverns, particularly at night, come alive. Russell Harlan's lighting is sparse, throwing long, hard shadows across the rooms; one striking shot captures the standoff between Dude and a group of tight-lipped men on Burdette's payroll from an overhead view, the stare-down framed by the shadowy recesses of the ceiling, and a bloodied man waiting behind a pillar with a gun. Patrolling after sundown, the pair find danger and menace lurking around every corner, with sudden noises (a neighing horse, or a gunshot) punctuating the nervous energy in the air.On the surface, Rio Bravo is a pure, red-blooded American western, a full-bodied tonic for the patriot in the wake of High Noon. While Billy Wilder's Some Like It Hot pushed against the boundaries of the Hays Code in the same year, Hawks' film represented a return to normalcy. The rules of the game are clear cut and simple. Shoot a man and it's murder, unless he has a gun, in which case it's upholding the law. A man's worth is determined by how quick he is on the draw, and his life, mere gold pieces. Women? Window dressing, unless you're Feathers and as stubborn as a mule, in which case you become an honourary member of the posse. But even she yields to Wayne eventually.Chance, unlike Gary Cooper's Will Kane, does not ever admit he needs help, nor does he make an overt show of asking for it. Wayne, at the height of his career, was enough; strutting around with a glare and rifle, he was the living embodiment of the dutiful sheriff, the heroic figure, reaffirming his moral authority with every growl. But look who answers the call anyway. A old timing cripple, a kid gunslinger, the local drunk, a Mexican innkeeper, and a gambler; an endearing band of misfits if there ever was one. They sing and smoke together (whether it be cigarettes or villains), and have each other's backs. Wayne's tough exterior never truly cracks, but he comforts and protects in his own way. Look at his sneer of disapproval at Dude quitting and running back to the bottle; it's almost enough to force the whiskey back in. And during the film's most tender moment, the narrative pauses while three cowboys sing along to the soft strumming of a guitar. In an era of tough men and political divide, as Mark Cousins puts it, this might be the closest thing to a family the western frontier had. Chance is there, too. He does not sing, but he just might be humming along.

It's hard to go wrong with a western with a cast that includes John Wayne, Dean Martin, Walter Brennan, Ward Bond, John Russell and Claude Akins, and with a master director like Howard Hawks. The by-play between the characters, the overlapping dialog (a Hawks trademark), the bursts of violent action all contribute to an almost perfect film. There are, however, two drawbacks that keep it from being just about perfect, one minor and one major. The minor one is Angie Dickinson. While a competent actress, she just doesn't seem to click with Wayne onscreen (although she has stated she clicked with him very well offscreen). She tries hard, and she does have her moments in the film, but overall her part drags the film down a bit. The major obstacle, though, is Ricky Nelson. It's blatantly obvious that he was brought into the movie to draw in the teenagers, as he was a major singing star of the time. He's so laid-back he's almost comatose; he mumbles his lines, and when you can understand him it sounds like he's talking in his sleep. The film comes to a screeching halt whenever he starts to talk, and even in the action scenes it loooks like he's doing everything in slow motion. You don't believe for a second that he's a tough Texas gunfighter; he looks more like a schoolboy playing hooky and hanging out with the older guys. However, Nelson isn't onscreen all the time, and when he isn't, everything clicks to make an almost perfect western . . . almost.

reviews.review_title: John Wayne and Western, a deadly Combo which never failed. Here's Another Classic!
reviews.content:
Rio Bravo (1959) :
Brief Review -John Wayne and Western, a deadly Combo which never failed. Here's Another Classic! John Wayne Fan Clubs might have put a bio in their social media profiles if available in those days saying, "John Wayne in Western, Nobody does it better". Rio Bravo is a solid proof that how simple yet excellent a western drama could be with no further intentional implications and efforts. It's just so fine without any mess, twist and thrill. A small-town sheriff in the American West enlists the help of a cripple, a drunk, and a young gunfighter in his efforts to hold in jail the brother of the local bad guy. An ordinary looking script on paper is built by extraordinary vision of director Howard Hawks. Not to forget he's the same man who had several classics in Comedy, Thriller, Noir genres and yet he grabbed the core of western genre much before we saw universal classics in the same genre. Rio Bravo has engaging screenplay and tight orders of all sequences that can be enjoyed in repeat viewing too. It has good comedy too, such a rare thing in dark Western genre. The background score is designed perfectly to help the scenes look more impactful. I kind of like so many things about this film that i even forget to mention some, nevertheless, i would go on with the mandatory ones. John Wayne delivers yet another remarkable performance as Sheriff. Like i said, nobody does it better than him when it comes to perfection in the characters for Western dramas. Rio Bravo is yet another feather on his hat that will shine with Colours forever. Angie Dickinson looks hot, Dean Martin, Ricky Nelson were good too but a real surprise was Walter Brennan. What an amazing act it was. What a great dialogue delivery and accent he had, Terrific. Overall, an evergreen Classic Western Drama by Wayne-Hawks pair.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest

This movie is an excellent western. John Wayne is John Wayne and that is almost always a good thing. Ricky Nelson does a good job as the gun fighter and doesn't over act the part. Walter Brennan is hilarious as Stumpy, the cantankerous deputy. The main plot is a lot like the one from El Dorado with the drunken, broken down, friend who is also the sheriff getting straightened out and brought back to being the tough lawman that runs the town again. Ward Bond has what is almost a cameo but does his usual fine job. I have never really cared for Angie Dickenson and her role here is no exception. I found her acting to be very flat and uninspired, almost like she was just going through the motions. Except for her though I think this another very good one by the Duke.

reviews.review_title: not since "Johnny Guitar" has the west felt so surreal
reviews.content: One of John Wayne's "I'm gonna wear this red shirt again" Westerns, a weird mixture of brutal, adult-oriented realism and Broadway sentiment.Dean Martin's drunken tough guy has a genuine friendship with John Wayne's John Wayne impression, and their relationship, as conveyed by the one of them who can act, is complex and rooted in true emotion. The bad guys are really awful killers. The town is appropriately dangerous and shabby. Certainly the violence is portrayed as shocking and terrible. But every once in a while Ricky and Dean start strummin', sometimes strollin' and singin' down the streets they've littered with corpses. It's strange.Hawks, though not young, could still direct, and he was old enough and in comfortable enough company to just sort of meander around and create some fun scenes without concerning himself overmuch with the big picture. As a result, we have Walter Brennan over the top as a bizarre and ancient incarnation of the gimp in "Red River", delivering himself of the corniest monologues of a long and corny career, juxtaposed with a grinning and sadistic Wayne knocking out a man's teeth with a rifle barrel.

reviews.review_title: Howard Hawks, the genre-hopping Hollywood maven sprightly riding on one of his better days
reviews.content: Allegedly, Howard Hawks' jaunty response to the daunting self-centeredness and pessimism permeated in Fred Zinnemann's revisionist Western classic HIGH NOON (1952), RIO BRAVO reunites Hawks with marquee star John Wayne, over a decade after their last enterprise RED RIVER (1948), the whole enchilada entirely takes place in the titular Texan town and Wayne plays sheriff John T. Chance, who gallantly takes a local murderer Joe Burdette (Akins) into custody, then stoutheartedly awaits the ominously forthcoming jailbreaking attempt from the gangs of the latter's bigwig rancher brother Nathan (Russell), a situation not dissimilar from the nettle Gary Cooper's small-town marshal Will Kane has to grasp in HIGH NOON.However, even John T. has only an alcoholic deputy Dude (Martin) and a gammy jailer named Stumpy (Brennan) on his side, he doesn't care about soliciting extraneous aid which Kane arduously seeks out...reading my full review on my blog: cinema omnivore, thanks

reviews.review_title: The working title of the film was A BULL BY THE TAIL.
reviews.content: RIO BRAVO was both produced and directed by Howard Hawks. The working title of the film was A BULL BY THE TAIL. The screenplay was written by Jules Furthman and Leigh Brackett and loosely based on a short story by B.H. McCampbell. Which is an inside joke B.H. McCampbell was Hawks' daughter Barbara. But according to Hawks, she only came up with the ending. Most of the story is by Leigh Brackett (THE BIG SLEEP & THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK) & what Hawks came up with while shooting. John Wayne had worked once before with Hawks, back in 1948 (RED RIVER.) Hawks wanted to make RIO BRAVO as a reaction to - HIGH NOON a complete inversion in every detail. Both movies unfold chronologically, but where HIGH NOON takes place in real time, RIO BRAVO sets a surprisingly leisurely pace telling a story spread across three days. Hawks said the only thing he did like about HIGH NOON was the music by Dimitri Tiomkin; but in contrast to HIGH NOON's ballad that only the audience could hear, RIO BRAVO's score included a trumpet dirge that weighs on the characters minds. The Hollywood Reporter review described composer Dimitri Tiomkin's scoring of a "bullfight trumpet" playing "El Deguelo" as "one of the film's most vital elements of suspense." Notice the great care with which the screenplay lays out its material -- in what is essentially a cinematic chess game. Every key character and plot element is introduced early along with the relationships that drive them, leading move after move to the violent end. The simple storyline has a sheriff take on, not 4 like in HIGH NOON, but 40 bad guys with some unexpected backup from the least likely characters - an alcoholic drifter, a crippled, elderly man, a naive young gunslinger, a dance-hall girl, and a hotel clerk. John Wayne was at the peak of his career in 1958 and Howard Hawks could not think of a better actor to play this lawman who embodied duty, decency, and integrity. It contains one of Wayne's best performances as Sheriff John T. Chance, playing what he himself called "the John Wayne role." He even wears the same hat, now battered and torn, that he had worn in Westerns ever since John Ford's "STAGECOACH" (1939). Much of the strength of the character comes from the way he holds himself in reserve, not feeling the need to comment on everything. When Dean Martin and Walter Brennan get in a loud argument, Hawks holds Wayne's character in the background, observing, not interfering. Wayne is always the unspoken source of authority, he is the audience the other characters hope to impress. Yet here he calls upon the role and his own history to bring nuance and depth to the character. Even grumpy old John Ford upon seeing John Wayne back in Howard Hawks' earlier western film "RED RIVER," said of Wayne "I never knew the big son of a bitch could act."It has surprisingly warm romantic chemistry between Wayne and Angie Dickinson in her first major film role (she turned 78 on Sept. 30, 2009.) He never sweet-talks Dickinson's character and indeed tends to be gruff toward her, but his eyes and body language speak for him as he (and we too) fall for her. Actress Angie Dickinson's role was compared in several reviews to the role played by Lauren Bacall in another film directed by Hawks, TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT. Dickinson absolutely holds the screen against the big man. She's not a saloon floozy but a competent professional gambler accustomed to sparring with men. The film opens on Ward Bond, a wonderful character actor (his 22nd film with John Wayne) and his last major film role. Peter Bogdanovich praises the long opening sequence in "Rio Bravo," which runs, nearly, five minutes without dialogue. Hawks said he wanted to get back to his silent film roots, where the tools of story telling with out dialogue pulled the audiences in much better than the pabulum of the masses called television which in the 1950s was killing the movies. Dean Martin was trying to prove he could make it on his own. Old Walter Brennan, as the peg-legged deputy, provides comic support. And, people forget he is one of only 3 actors to win three Oscars. In a lull in the action, the men relax inside the barricaded sheriff's office, and Martin, resting on his back with his hat shielding his eyes, begins to sing about a cowboy's loneliness. Nelson picks up his guitar and accompanies him. Then Ricky sings an uptempo song of his own, with Martin and even Brennan in harmony. Martin and Nelson were two of the most popular singers of the time, and the interlude functions well as an affectionate reprise for the men before the final showdown. RIO BRAVO was one of Wayne and Hawks's most successful and satisfying vehicles, which may help explain why they liked it so much and were so impressed with its potential for further exploration, that they remade it twice, once as EL DORADO and once as RIO LOBO.

reviews.review_title: A classic with a few minor flaws.
reviews.content: Yep, all you "Pulp Fiction" junkies can rush out to the DVD stores - this is one of Quentin Tarantino's "top three" favorite films, along with "Taxi Driver" and "Blow Out." Slightly irreverent top favorites, I'd say, except for "Driver." This was basically loosely remade by John Carpenter in 1976 with ASSAULT ON PRECINCT 13, which was much faster-moving and an excellent film, but this one is also rather terrific, if slower. (Which, in this case, is a good thing.) A sheriff in a small town in southwest Texas must keep custody of a murderer whose brother is trying to help him escape. After a friend is killed trying to muster support for him, he and his deputies - a disgraced drunk and a cantankerous old cripple - must find a way to hold out against the rancher's hired guns until the marshal arrives. In the meantime, matters are complicated by the presence of a young gunslinger - and a mysterious beauty who just came in on the last stagecoach.I wouldn't say this is one of THE favorite films of mine but it is a great film that set the course for many to follow - expertly directed by Hawks and all-around an influential, enjoyable semi-masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: Character driven western with great cast and plenty of action
reviews.content: Enjoyable and fun character-driven "shoot 'em up" style western, featuring an appealing ensemble cast.John Wayne is town marshal "John T.", and he has none other than the likes of Dean Martin, Ricky Nelson, and Walter Brennan as his battery of dead-eye-shootin' deputies. Considering they played characters named, respectively, "Dude," "Colorado," and "Stumpy, you know these guys had a blast making this movie. Angie Dickinson is terrific to look at as usual, and plays Wayne's romantic interest.They're holed up in the town jail, guarding a prisoner (Claude Akins), whose powerful brother is trying to bust him out. The action is typical John Wayne/Howard Hawks (director) fare: frequent gun play and action, mixed with humorous, snappy dialog, as the film good-naturedly pokes fun at itself. (Who would expect a singing collaboration of Martin, Nelson, and Brennan?) Martin's character is a drunk trying to dry out--that sounds like an "insert joke here" setup, not to mention an old western cliché. But Martin's acting is strong and effective--Dude is a character that is developed well and is integral to the storyline. Brennan perfected his "old geezer sidekick" routine (frequently imitated by others), and Nelson obviously got a kick out of his "young gunfighter" role. Wayne is, of course, patriarchal, and predictably good at shooting bad guys.A cleverly done final confrontation between the two camps does not disappoint after the build-up throughout the movie. Definitely recommended for western fans, and Wayne fans, but even other viewers should find this movie a good watch.

reviews.review_title: A sparkling Western and one of Wayne's greatest.
reviews.content: "Rio Bravo" is a Western that's typical of John Wayne. He plays a squeaky-clean, upstanding law enforcer, someone who is quite easy-going until provoked and always believes in doing the right thing. That was the image John Wayne stuck with for most of his career and it works in "Rio Bravo." There is plenty of fun in this film, thanks to some good dialogue, being quite lighthearted in places, the story being pretty good and also for featuring some great action near the end. Dean Martin gives a better than average performance as the former sheriff who deals with his own demons via the bottle. He eventually finds his courage and regains some of his former glory. Old hands like Walter Brennan and Ward Bond give their usual sterling support, they were veterans of the Western genre. The running time is a bit long at 130 minutes but I personally don't find that a problem. In a town not far from the Mexican border, an outlaw is being held in the town jail. For John Wayne, that means the entire gang of which the outlaw is a member, shall be riding into town with the intention of springing their comrade. Wayne only has a drunken former sheriff, a deputy with a crippled leg and a young and inexperienced gunfighter for support. The direction from Howard Hawks keeps the film ticking along at a good pace. Wayne's movies with Hawks are equally as good as the ones he made with John Ford.

Howard Hawks directs John Wayne, Walter Brennan, Dean Martin in a Western about a town where the Sheriff (Wayne) needs help to stop a gang invasion and gets it from a group of friends who are not all that reliable.The late Rick Nelson made one of his earlier screen roles here away from Ozzie and the rest of the family. Dean Martin was not that long from breaking up with Jerry Lewis when he did this picture.Overall this movie is solid vehicle though the differences between this and the redo El Dorado about 7 years later are mainly in the casting. Robert Mitchum has Dean Martins role & James Caan in the Ricky Nelson role. The pleasure of seeing this is in the fact that a very good cast & very good director make a good solid film. Hawks directed the remake too.

Rio Bravo has an emotional connection with me which makes reviewing it objectively virtually impossible. It is just about the most perfect example in a film, that I have ever witnessed, of action blended with a philosophy of living. Howard Hawks would, no doubt, scoff at such a description--but that is my feeling about it.I first saw the picture when I was about 10 years old in a Saturday matinée at my local theater. The theater was packed with other kids around the same age as myself.The scene that will always live with me from that theater experience, is when, near the end of the picture, two bad guys have managed to dodge John Wayne's bullets and are coming up behind him. We see the two bad men blown away by two shotgun blasts and then we hear the familiar cackle of Stumpy, played by Walter Brennan. When that cackle was heard in the theater that afternoon, the kids in that theater erupted spontaneously into cheers. In some visceral, indefinable way, we kids identified with Stumpy, and his "supposed uselessness'. And when Stumpy was vindicated in that moment, we felt vindicated.Rio Bravo has many moments like that, especially with its dialog. When Feathers asks Chance what he thinks she should do to avoid being unfairly harassed by lawmen wherever she goes, Chance suggests that she stop dressing the way she does. Feathers looks straight at Chance and says, "That's the kind of thing I'd do, if I was the kind of girl you think I am, sheriff." Rio Bravo is a deliberately slow movie. And in its deliberateness, Rio Bravo examines a number of different themes. Some of them are: Rio Bravo is an exploration of what loyalty means. Besides the obvious loyalty of Chance and Dude and Stumpy, there is the example of Chance's friend Wheeler, who ends up dying for his loyalty. And Carlos the hotel owner, who by the end has come up to help Chance--with a shotgun that is as big as he is. But again, there is the dialog, such as when Chance hands Dude his own set of guns, that Dude had pawned long ago for a drink. Dude looks up at Chance as they are walking, "You've been holding these all this time?" Chance replies, "Been waiting till they fit you again".Rio Bravo is also an exploration of what bravery is. Again, there are the obvious scenes of bravery involving Chance, Dude and Colorado. But there is also the scene, for instance, of Feathers, sitting in a chair asleep in the morning--outside of Chance's bedroom at the hotel. She has obviously been "standing guard" all night. Chance exasperatedly chides her for this, but her bravery is undeniable and touching But most of all, I think that Rio Bravo is an exploration of friendship, and what it can mean for us to have a friend by our side, through it all, no matter what.As a young boy, watching this movie years ago on the big screen, it had a profound effect on me. Like Mia Farrow in Woody Allen's The Purple Rose of Cairo, I felt like I was transported into the screen. Whenever I watch Rio Bravo, it still has the same impact for me.I can't say that about too many other movies.

This would definitely could have been a better film, perhaps a classic. But it was too long, and the pace lagged at times. The inclusion of the two songs was probably so Ricky Nelson could made the teenage girls happy, but certainly were out of place. Ricky Nelson was completely out of place in the role of Colorado. Walter Brennan's performance was totally over-the-top and ludicrous. But the biggest drawback was the contrived and totally unconvincing romance between Wayne and Angie Dickinson. It would have been much better if it had simply been left out of the film along with Dickinson herself. Her performance was so bad that one didn't know whether to laugh or to feel sorry for her.

RIO BRAVO is one of the most entertaining films ever! It's one of those films that I can watch repeatedly without ever getting bored. If you're a fan of John Wayne, then THIS is the perfect film for you. Wayne is effortless in his portrayal of the movie's hero Sheriff John T. Chance. He was so natural in Westerns, born to play in them. No matter how challenging or different the role, Wayne always thrived in Westerns. And he rarely played the same character, which is ironic since many thought he was typecast as the Western hero. You're telling me that the heroic everyman John T. Chance is the same as the disturbed, racist Ethan Edwards (THE SEARCHERS) or the stubborn pioneer John Dunston (RED RIVER)? I don't think so. And Mr. Wayne played all these challenging roles with amazing accuracy and aplomb. The man could act! I've seen some say that this role for Wayne was 'easy' for him b/c he just got to play himself. One thing is for sure: Wayne completely carries this long film from start to finish! The characters are what drive RIO BRAVO. The plot isn't so much important. But Chance is holding local thug and killer Joe Burdett (effectively played by Claude Akins) in jail while waiting for the territory marshal to pick him up. All the help Chance has are his 2 deputies Dude (brilliantly played by Dean Martin) and Stumpy (the funny Walter Brennan). Special mention should go to Martin, who has to have given the best performance of his career in this film. He realistically relays the role of the alcoholic who is truly trying to change. It's actually amazing that they put such a powerful topic in a film like this, but it completely works. Also, Martin is NOT a supporting character in this film. He is essentially the second lead next to Wayne.Brennan is as usual a card as Wayne's sidekick. Also in supporting roles are Angie Dickinson and Ricky Nelson, who are both a little immature for their roles, but still both do a fine job with what they are given to work with. Main kudos go to Wayne and Martin in the acting department. The director Howard Hawks creates a special, isolated world in this tiny Texas burg. The dialogue is especially simple, but yet situations and characters are so well-defined, you almost feel like you are spying in on this world, rather than watching a 'movie'.

"Rio Bravo" has much in common with "High Noon" (1952, Fred Zinnemann). In both films a little town is awaiting the vengeance of a dreaded rogue. In "High Noon" because the rogue was trapped by the Marshal of the town and was recently released. In "Rio Bravo" the Sheriff has put his brother in prison."Rio Bravo" not only has much in common with "High Noon", in fact it is a reaction on this film. In "High Noon" the Marshal is looking for help in vain and is on his own in his struggle against the criminal. "High Noon" is in essence a very pessimistic film. Too pessimistic in the opinion of the makers of "Rio Bravo", especially lead actor John Wayne, and they made a more heroic Western in which the Sheriff does get help from different people.In my opinion "High Noon" is the better film, but "Rio Bravo" is not bad either. It was the come back film of Howard Hawks, after (the failure of) "Land of the Pharaos" (1955), and he proved that he had not forget his trade. The emphasis on the film is not on the battle with the criminals (although the shootout is spectacular ebough) , but on the dynamics in the inner circle of the Sheriff.The centre of the inner circle is of course Sheriff John T. Chance hilmself, a subdued and remarkable "un-tough" role of John Wayne. Dean Martin plays his assistent who has problems with the bottle. Walter Brennan (winning in his career three Oscars for best supporting actor) plays old Stumpy. He is the comic relief of the movie and his humour is well dosed. Ricky Nelson, at that time a rival of Elvis Presley, plays the overconfident boy. Of course he gets his own song in the movie to promote himself. Most striking in this inner circle is the young Angie Dickinson as "Feathers", the love interest of John T. Chance. Despite the quite large age difference (27 vs 51) the chemistry between the two is undeniably one of the gems of the movie.

Amiable and largely entertaining, "Rio Bravo" is all that Hollywood westerns strive to be and about as far from the actual west as films likely get. With such western stalwarts as John Wayne, Walter Brennan, and Ward Bond working under the direction of Howard Hawks, what more could a western aficionado ask for? The bad guys, headed by John Russell and Claude Aikens, snarl, wear black hats, and act like unrequited villains to the end. The good guys smile, always hit their targets, and bond despite differences in age, sobriety, and vocal skills. Why, the good guys even loll around the sheriff's office strumming guitars and crooning songs. Did Wyatt Earp really strike up duets with Doc Holliday? Never mind, "Rio Bravo" does not strive for authenticity, just rousing fun.The three western veterans that head the cast, Wayne, Brennan, and Bond, have performed in so many horse operas that the dust of the open plains is lodged in their lungs. Although Dean Martin's slick image initially works against him, he tries hard and eventually convinces the audience that, even if he does not fit the image of a gunslinger, he is a fine sensitive actor, when given the chance. Unfortunately, one singer was not enough for Hawks, and he evidently hired Ricky Nelson to attract teenage girls to the film. Whatever Ricky Nelson was, a sharp shooting gunman he was not. His acting skills were honed on "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet," and they do not carry him here against heavyweights such as Wayne and Brennan. His voice and American Bandstand haircut are 1950's New Jersey, not 1880's frontier. Although Angie Dickinson is also coiffed out of period, she does well as the leading lady, who inexplicably pursues Wayne. Why the leggy twenty-something would overlook the dark good looks of Martin or the baby face of Nelson for craggy middle-aged Wayne is one of the plot's deeper mysteries.At 141 minutes, "Rio Bravo" runs long, and the aforementioned crooning scene could have been judiciously trimmed, although the teenyboppers would have likely protested. Tightening the scenes between Wayne and Dickinson would not have hurt either. Her coy come-ons to the fatherly Wayne are not convincing in any case. However, despite the quibbles, "Rio Bravo" will satisfy most with its humor, genial performances, classic good-guys-versus-bad-guys storyline, gunfights, fistfights, and male bonding. And, yes, even Martin's mellow voice and Nelson's guitar plucking are pleasant diversions. However, "Rio Bravo" does not depict how the west was really won. Gunshots are bloodless, hotel rooms are freshly painted, and women play poker with the guys. Perhaps, "Rio Bravo" shows how the west should have been.

Rio bravo is from now one my favourite western that i saw,in future that could change cause before watching this one,magnificent seven was on number one so it is possible that i will admire some western even more in future but it will be hard to top this one,that is mostly because of great cast and great and enterteining story that worked in every way possible,john wayne may have a lot of haters because of his politics staff and opinions but none person cant say that he cant act,he was brilliant here,ricky nelson and dean martin were also awesome and interesting characters with a lot of personality and likeablite,gunfights and direction were also done rather well,and it left a big trademark for future movies of genre,rio bravo was for me a great movie with brilliant staff in it

reviews.review_title: John Wayne, Dean Martin and Ricky Nelson Draw a Crowd for Howard Hawks
reviews.content: "On one side is an army of gunmen dead-set on springing a murderous cohort from jail. On the other is Sheriff John T. Chance (John Wayne) and his two deputies: one a recovering drunkard (Dean Martin), the other a crippled codger (Walter Brennan). Also in their ragtag ranks are an unseasoned, trigger-happy youth (Ricky Nelson) and a woman with a past (Angie Dickinson) - and her eye on Chance. Director Howard Hawks lifted the Western to new heights with 'Red River'. Capturing the legendary West with a stellar cast in peak form, he does it again here," according to the Special Edition DVD description.Mr. Hawks' "Red River" is in a class of its own, and though "Rio Bravo" does not approach the heights promised by the above comparison, it's still an excellent film. Hawks goes off on some tangents, but they're worth watching; it's not really that "Rio Bravo" is too long, but that some of its length seems not to add much. Interesting, too, is how Mr. Wayne further develops his persona under Hawks' direction. Perhaps unexpectedly, Mr. Martin excels in a dramatic role which seems written for him. Mr. Nelson exudes youthful sex appeal like few other teen idols. There is certainly a lot of charisma on screen.Martin and Nelson were both very successful in another field, and you'll hear a sample. Johnny Cash wrote a superb song for Rick to sing in this film, which appeared on his "Ricky Sings Again" LP and was the lead track of a hit EP. A listen to the song "Restless Kid" will reveal why it wasn't included. It couldn't be a title song since it is about Nelson's "Colorado" character exclusively. And if inserted where Nelson and Martin sing a couple of folksy tunes, "Restless Kid" would have stopped the show. Come to think about it, that might not have been a bad idea. Still, see "Rio Bravo" for some iconic performances.******** Rio Bravo (3/18/59) Howard Hawks ~ John Wayne, Dean Martin, Ricky Nelson, Angie Dickinson

'Rio Bravo' throws you in at the feet of the oppressors, while the civilians are thrown in over their heads.It's the typical western - a people dependent on violence even when it's least constructive - that's all these broken people know, and to change is even harder than living in pain.

If you like westerns, this is actually a quite polished example. The Mexicans are stereotyped, but the film was made in 1958 when this was normal movie fare. There are no Indians in the film. John Wayne can only play John Wayne, and he does so successfully here. Ricky Nelson is a bit overmatched by his role. Dean Martin displays more acting range than I expected. Walter Brennan plays Walter Brennan with a cranky old man's accent.It's decent entertainment.

reviews.review_title: This movie has everything you could ask for from the western genre
reviews.content: Rio Bravo (1959) is a movie I recently watched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a sheriff with limited resources and many problems on the way. He hires a town drunk to be his deputy and an old man to protect his jail. When he arrest a local bandit and is waiting for national authorities to come get him, time is not on his side as the gang will try to breakout their arrested friend. A love interest and young cowboy joins the band of misfits to help the sheriff.This movie is directed by Howard Hawks (The Big Sleep) and stars John Wayne (True Grit), Dean Martin (The Silencers), Angie Dickinson (Point Blank), Walter Brennan (To Have and Have Not), Estelita Rodriguez (The Golden Stallion), Claude Akins (Battle for Planet of the Apes) and Ricky Nelson (The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet).This movie has some fantastic characters that make it an absolute must see. Dean Martin was an entertaining and unpredictable character. Angie Dickinson was smoking hot. The hotel scenes were always fun and of course Wayne was a great main character. The old man was also hilarious, especially the scenes were he shot at, or almost shot at, various characters. The ending had some good twists for our heroes and the resolve makes you smile.This movie has everything you could ask for from the western genre. I would score this a 9/10 and strongly recommend it.

Let me start out by saying this: Dean Martin should have been a country singer. Wow. The scene where he and Ricky Nelson go at it with the guitar and harmonica accompaniment is amazing. It made every hair on my arm stand up."Rio Bravo" is a happy, funny, feel-good Hollywood western. I liked it more than I liked "Red River" because it makes no bones about being 'Hollywood.' It takes pride in the colorful costumes, the cheeseball comedy and the light-hearted dialog. There is no great violence here. I'd say a kid could watch this one no problem.Normally, I don't like these kind of westerns, but this one left a good taste in my mouth. I will probably revisit it within the next few months, it's just a fun movie.7 out of 10, kids.

reviews.review_title: Superb western with great music cameos.
reviews.content: John Wayne at his best. Plus a great Dean Martin song. So good

reviews.review_title: "Rio Bravo" makes it clear to see what made The Duke a legend
reviews.content: For a guy who's never seen a John Wayne movie, I figured "Rio Bravo" would make a great intro. Wayne's salt-of-the-earth persona is put to good use here as the aging sheriff who's tasked with keeping a prisoner locked up while defending the town from some pretty persuasive gunmen looking to free the murderer. Helping out our hero is a sobering-up deputy (Dean Martin), an old cripple (Walter Brennan) and an eager young gunfighter (Rick Nelson). Angie Dickinson is also hanging around to get under Wayne's skin and look gorgeous for the camera.It's an epic revenge oater with lenty of buildup and a legendary shootout to cap things off. There's an authentic friendship between Wayne and Dino, and plenty of playful back-and-forth between John Wayne and Angie Dickinson. And it's that set of well-drawn characters that keeps the leisurely-paced western from slowing down. 7.5/10

For those used to seeing Big John Wayne galloping all over the wide open spaces of the Old West, RIO BRAVO will come as something of a shock, as most of the movie takes place on two interior sets, a jailhouse and a saloon/hotel. Wayne plays a small town sheriff who locks up a killer (Claude Akins), and the killer's brother and gang come to bust him out any way they can. The sheriff only has an old galoot named Stumpy (Walter Brennan) and a drunken deputy (Dean Martin) to help him. Most of the action is saved for the big showdown at the end. Much of the rest of the movie is a character study. Hardly Howard Hawks' best work, but worth a look. Martin disappears from a sizable segment of the story, supposedly because he runs off for a time. Once he returns, the movie seems oddly disjointed, and I have no idea what might have happened. A virtually unrecognizable Angie Dickinson is on hand as a troubled woman who falls for Big John, and a teenaged Ricky Nelson plays a Billy the Kid type who eventually sides with the good guys. . The movie has been remade four times, twice as a western and twice as an urban crime thriller.

A fun, well made and highly entertaining film. One of John Wayne's best and all the supporting characters are played perfectly.The action and character interactions are highlights of the film and the lazed, fun, hangout pace make it a unique and ahead of its time film.

A classic Hawks western, "Rio Bravo" succeeds on every level.  Apart from an excellent, well told story, great action sequences, and great cinematography, it also has a human story with some character development, with Dean Martin playing a drunk struggling to put himself back together, and John Wayne playing a sheriff forced to honorably do his duty, a la Gary Cooper in "High Noon", although this movie is intended to be the opposite of "High Noon" in almost every respect.  At over two hours long, it is slow paced, but that allows the characters and the story to unfold well.  One of the finest westerns ever made, and one of Hawks' best films.

reviews.review_title: Bravo, Mr. Hawks for this tale of pure bravado filled with so many bravura performances...
reviews.content: "High Noon" is one of my all-time favorite westerns and I really believed a film couldn't be the antithesis of a masterpiece and a masterpiece. I was a fool and "Rio Bravo" was a fantastic experience.I can't recall one scene that didn't grab me or touch me or made me laugh or smile. The acting and writing blended into a flawless story, smoothly directed by Howard Hawks at the top of his game. Each episode enriches the psychology of the characters -villains included- exploring every Western trope while deviating from the tiresome norms... and basically retelling the "High Noon" story with a new angle. A successful one.It's common knowledge that Hawks loathed "High Noon" because of its portrayal of a marshal asking townspeople to help him, a move he deemed as unprofessional. Wayne didn't beat around the bush and called it "un-American". Whether the two were right or wrong is irrelevant, Hawks applied the 'Godard' principle: the best way to criticize a film is to make one. After "Rio Bravo", I finally could hear what he and Wayne kept saying.Now, "Rio Bravo" doesn't open with a catchy ballad like its rival but its opening is nonetheless brilliant by pure cinematic standards. No words spoken for five minutes. Dean Martin enters the bar, his eye language suggests a lost man at the verge of breaking down. We gather he needs a fuel. He's Dude and Martin's acting was so incredible I hardly recognized the glamorous singer. A man, Joe Burdette (Claude Atkins) asks him if it's about drinking -no words spoken again- Dude nods, Joe throws a coin in the spittoon. Dude kneels down to take it but is stopped by a Winchester, the extension of a body that can only belong to one man: John Wayne. He shakes his head and kick the vase out of Dude's reach.Dimitri Tiomkin's music that has followed the action rhythm like in old silent films, goes crescendo as violence escalates. Dude knocks the Duke down, a fight ensues and a man who tried to interfere is brutally shot by Joe. The ruthless killer goes to another saloon where he's finally arrested by Sherif Chance (Wayne) with Dude's help. Je is taken to the jail where we meet Stumpy, the two-teeth limping deputy played by the unique Walter Brennan, the actor who always seems in his element when he plays supporting comedic characters. And that's it, in a school-case of minimalist directing we get half the cast established and whole set-up. Joe's got a brother and many supporters in town. Until he's taken to the marshal, surveillance is needed, it's the "High Noon" situation stretched for days.The plot builds up to the part where an old friend of Chance, Ward Bond in his final role, offers his help but Chance dismisses it: men are paid to free Burdette, why would he make widows or orphans for such a worthless sacrifice? (A subtle "Take That" to "High Noon") Then there's Ricky Nelson as Colorado Ryan, one of Bond's employees. Nelson is as believable a cowboy as if they had cast Elvis instead, but he is just as cool as James Coburn in "The Magnificent Seven". When Wayne talks about him in his presence, Ryan says "I understand English, you can ask me", and when offered the chance to help, he'd rather "mind his own business", this is not cowardice, but pragmatism.And Chance admires a man so capable he doesn't feel like proving it. In a film where even the little Mexican hotel owner Carlos (Pedro Rodriguez) ends up proving he's more than a comic relief, we get the point: men you can count on need no "calling", if you need them, they will come. And as if the story wasn't multilayered enough, and to spice it up with a romance with the Duke, Hawks gratifies us with one strong female character played by Angie Dickinson. The beautiful and flirtatious Feathers knows she's dealing with a poker-faced man, one of few words; and so she carefully chooses hers, loading them with the right amount of wit and sexual innuendo. The dialogue between Dickinson and Wayne, reminded me of Hawks' laws of attraction in his screwball classics and movies like "To Have and Have Not" or "The Big Sleep". Wayne never makes the moves, but gives enough rope to be reached little by little, not good at acting but at reacting.Indeed, I praised Dean Martin's acting not just because of the poignantly sinuous road of his redemption or his total insecurity, but also because it inspired the best of Wayne's reacting skills. Don't let his seeming expressionlessness fool you: the trick with Wayne is to never show that he's scared or worried while allowing the attentive viewers to sense a certain vulnerability. "Rio Bravo" is full of subtle moments, generally silent, that'd make you believe this one of the Duke's best performances... also one where he can gives a big kiss to Brennan's head before getting kicked with a broom. You never get too much sentimental.Now, to the villains: they're not the one-dimensional ominous-looking trigger-happy thugs: Joe's brother (John Russel) tries to lay the diplomatic card while maneuvering in the shadows. But as Chance warns him, if something ever goes wrong, his sibling might be "accidentally" shot before anyone frees him, Stumpy approves with a glee that shows that they mean business. And what if things escalate? It wouldn't matter, they'll all be dead. The arrogance is calculated but pays off in the way it makes the enemy equally cautious and ingenuous and the whole confrontation a little more a battle of guns. In fact, everything in "Rio Bravo" is a little more than what you'd expect ... and if I concluded my "High Noon" review saying "with all due respect, Mr. Hawks, Wayne and Ebert, "High Noon" is perfect the way it is". Let me add with the same due respect:"So is "Rio Bravo".

i really like this Western.it stars John Wayne,Ricky Nelson,Dean martin and Angie Dickinson,to name a few.the acting is superb in this movie.but what i really like is the dialogue and the unique mix of characters.the story is also good.it's straightforward and simple.Unlike The Searchers,another John Wayne movie.Rio bravo is not a sweeping,grand epic.it takes place in basically one town.nevertheless,i found it engaging and compelling.this edition contains a raft of extras,including two documentaries and a short featurette.Like the Ultimate edition of The Searchers,here is also a reproduction of the 1959 Dell comic book,a reproduction of the original press book from 1959,and 8 full colour lobby cards.as for the movie itself,i think it's pretty well done,and deserves a 7/10.the collection is definitely worth having,and i give that an 8/10.

reviews.review_title: Make time to see it; it's worth it...
reviews.content:
Some complain that Nelson is "sleep-walking" or "comatose." Others say that he mumbles. He does neither. All he really does is play the self-effacing, laconic young cowboy (of which the real West has NO shortage) quite well.
Others say that there is no chemistry between Wayne and Dickinson. Maybe not, but it does accurately capture the awkwardness one might expect in a similar situation.Those two minor criticisms aside, this is simply a great movie, a timeless classic, one for the ages. I could go on, but you get the idea. Bad guys have black hats, have people hired to play EL DEGUELLO, beat people out of their land, etc. Good guys have their weaknesses, often painfully obvious, but work through them anyway. This is a four star beauty and it will not give you a headache...

This is a truly excellent classic western directed by the legendary Howard Hawks. Its not simply good because it has the most popular actor of the sound era in the leading role but it strikes a cord with audiences like few other movies. It boasts a good storyline of morals and outsiders with plenty of action thrown in to satisfy the general western fan. The movie has become a cult in the 90's and is the favourite movie of several directors including John Carpenter. Watch out for Ricky and Deano singing and Duke facing up to the bad guys with a rag tag bunch of deputies. This really is a movie to add to your DVD collection, buy it now, you wont be disappointed.

John Wayne plays the part of Sheriff John T. Chance. When a local no-good kills an unarmed man, he takes him into custody pending the arrival of the U. S. Marshall in six or seven days. But the criminal's brother is a wealthy man who will use all his resources to retrieve his brother-legal and otherwise.Chance has a deputy who is a drunkard (Dean Martin) and another one (Walter Brennan) who is older and walks with a limp. Their odds against the gang are long, but they hope to hold out. Complications arise when visitors to the town become safety risks, diverting the sheriff's attention.Ricky Nelson plays a young gunman who knows better than to get involved. And Angie Dickinson is a fugitive who appears on the sheriff's radar.This is one of the better westerns. The story is entertaining for its humor and its suspense. Angie Dickinson, in particular, shines in her role.

I watched this film a few years ago and enjoyed it, but seeing it again this week I was not as impressed, and neither were the two people with me.Too long, as some other reviewers have said, and too slow. Maybe this is by today's standards, but still it seems slow. Directing, as some have said, is very good. Acting: Seems generally OK but sometimes is wooden, or as one of my companions said, you can tell they are acting.The film maybe tries to be too many things, but this again could be by comparison to modern films. Western, action, romance, comedy, musical, all in one film. Perhaps this helps to develop characters, as we see them in different situations. But I could have done without the singing scene especially.

Yes westerns are old-fashioned now but some of the old ones like this one are still good and pleasant to watch. This movie combines in a very realistic way suspense, action, sentiment and humour.
Howard Hawks has done very good movies between 1926 and 1970 not all of them westerns. This movie has great actors like John Wayne (one of Hawks' favourites) and Dean Martin who perform great roles here.
This is the simple story of a small town in Texas where a sheriff (John Wayne) has two assistants, one a drunkard (Dean Martin) and the other an old crippled man. He's got to face a powerful gang that is trying to free one of its members who was arrested for murder by the sheriff. The action develops itself in several episodes many of them violent but acceptable in terms of psychological and visual reality. A good film of its kind.

See it – The best of John Wayne's "Rio" movies. Unfortunately, it is too long, and if you'd like to watch a shorter, better version just watch "El Dorado." This western feels like a cowboy soap opera at certain points. The only time they even go outside the jail is to take a quick patrol and then its back to talking. Another complaint is the decision to stick 2 popular musicians in a western and expect us to take it seriously. I have a feeling Dean Martin and Ricky Nelson were chosen just for their duet we get to hear them sing. So why watch it? Well it's one of the most beloved and popular John Wayne westerns all time. It's charming, funny, and the showdown at the end is one of the most explosive film climaxes in the western genre.

reviews.review_title: A fine wrap-up to Hawks' career.
reviews.content: Although this wasn't Howard Hawks final film, it almost certainly was his last great film, one that transcended the usual standards of the genre and used character study and dialog to overshadow action sequences. Supposedly the conservative response to High Noon, Hawks and star John Wayne have created a glorious tribute to the Old West, as well as gathering a great supporting cast to help along the way.Wayne is perfect here is John T. Chance, with his slow drawl delivery and gimpy walk, he resembles a man who has witnessed plenty of evil in this small town and just wished it would go away. He has to try and keep a man from being sprung from jail and his only help is an old cripple named Stumpy (Walter Brennan in a scene-stealing role), a recovering drunk named Dude (Dean Martin in the best role of the film), and a quick, young sharpshooter named Colorado Ryan (Ricky Nelson in a very fine performance). All the elements come together here along with the strong writing which allows for the characters to embrace their own situations and work to resolve the one they are all in. The first hour or so simply sets up the background: Chance is the longtime sheriff, Dude is struggling to stay off the sauce, and a woman gets off the coach and immediately starts up a relationship with Chance.In another director's hands, this would be all action leading up to one final explosive scene. Here, action is minimal and used sparingly, so when the final action scene does come it is not only expected but exciting and satisfying. As I mentioned before, I though Dean Martin's performance was Oscar-worthy as a former drunk with plenty of problems, but realizes he needs to fix this one. It is such a great work of sympathy and desperation, you just feel for this guy and hope that he gets it all worked out. Certainly not the best Western I've ever seen, but this one works in Hawks' famous definition of a good movie: three great scenes, no bad ones. It was never more evident here.

reviews.review_title: Wooden characters and dialog--a waste of fine talent
reviews.content: I have a lot of trouble understanding the appeal of this Hawks retread. At times the characters seem to be just aimlessly killing time. There is some kind of in-joke at play here among the characters, but the "winking" saps the piece of any dramatic tension it might have had. Especially Duke and Angie seem to be standing in different countries in their scenes together. A roster of talent doing one-person shows. None of the characters appears to have a life beyond the immediate scene, and the clichéd dialog does little to advance the story. It seems to me that Hawks would have been better off taking this outing to the beach. It's beyond the viewer what the Wayne and Nelson characters are doing in the same room together.

reviews.review_title: Rio Bravo: Nothing can tear 'em apart!
reviews.content: 'Rio Bravo' is directed and produced by one of the best Hollywood-directors ever - Howard Hawks. After an opening scene that feels a bit dated, 'Rio Bravo' feels modern even if Hawks at times uses Dimitri Tiompkins music too much. Dean Martin and very young Ricky Nielsen are brutal with two revolvers each! Walter Brennan is the loyal and brave man, good and charming as usual. John Wayne is the natural leader and very trustworthy as sheriff.'Rio Bravo' is hardly slow, it is filled with action-packed and timeless gunfights. There are said that there are no close-ups in this film, but still some of it's style is inspiration for Sergio Leone's Westerns. And it is one of the most entertaining Westerns ever, with the rare ability to be booth funny, tough and exciting.The loyalty between the sheriff and the deputies are stronger than everything and in the end all four (Wayne, Nielsen, Martin and Brennan) wants, more than anything else, to be a part of the fellowship and then nothing can tear 'em apart!Rating: 9 of 10.

reviews.review_title: One of the all time great westerns bar none none.
reviews.content: This to me is the perfect western and can be watched again and again. Action Romance great background music and some great comedy moments in this movie with a great lead cast who each including John Wayne come out with at least a couple of laugh out loud lines! In my top 5 westerns of all time and I have seen a few. A great of its genre.

I'm a fan of Western since I was a child. Meanwhile, in the age of 50, I've changed positive thinking about of some of my favorites when I was young. But - beside John Fords monument "The Searchers" - Howard Hawks "Rio Bravo" is still of the pictures I love and admire more every year. This Western for me is one of the best films ever made. It found every involved artist in a top form: The actors, off course a giant performance of the Duke, impressive acting of Ricky Nelson and Angie Dickinson, Dean Martin at it's best as the drunken deputy and a wonderful Walter Brennan as the grumbling and slandering old sidekick Stumpy; Hawks intelligent and calm directing; the perfect dramatic and humorous script from Jules Furthman and Leigh Brackett; Russell Harlans indoor-photography; and at least the powerful music score from Dimitri Tiomkin, who did his best job since "High Noon", the Western which made Hawks so angry that he filmed "Rio Bravo". I love this picture, and I know some people who don't like this genre but love this outstanding great movie too!

Yet another Howard Hawks masterpiece is created in this thrilling western. Staring John Wayne as a lonely sheriff who's only company is an old cripple played by Walter Brennan and a former great law man now drunk played by Dean Martin. The trouble begins when John's character named Chance arrests a criminal whose brother is Nathan Brennan the most dangerous gang leader in the west. Nathan then comes to town to see if Chance would consider freeing his brother. Chance refuses sending the law and the bandits into a war against each other.This is my favorite western movie of all time as it is filled with action, adventure and mountains of excitement. Along with that, my favorite director Howard Hawks directs with unbelievable precision and compassion which was shown through this film unbelievably likable characters. Amazingly Ricky Nelson and Dean Martin pull out fantastic performances, which can be attributed to Hawks' direction.Beyond that this film includes everything that people love about westerns. Giant gun fights, characters larger than life, a beautiful women, the ultimate standoff of good and evil, and a truly marvelous story.

So if you were going to make a western, you'd perhaps compile a list of ingredients, or components, that you think will help to make your film a classic.Your thoughts might go like this: "First we need to have a boring, unrealistic romance between a 50-something year-old guy and a 20-something year-old girl. And we need to make sure that it takes up a lot of time in the bloated 140 minute production. Because nothing screams 'great western' like an unnecessary, unconvincing romance! Heck yeah we need that!""Let's see, what else....we should get some young musician who can't act very well and stick him in the film. And have him sing a song or two, songs that don't sound very vintage to the 19th century old west. This is a MUST to make a great western!""Hmm...and let's have some comic relief. Let's have this old guy walk around and complain and gripe about everything under the sun, because that's funny, right? And let's make his voice so annoying that it grates on your nerves, to the point where you're hoping somebody, anybody, kills this character off. Gotta have that or it's not a great western.""The plot has to be inanely stupid. The bad guys are all around town but they don't do very much. They just watch you. They are willing to kill the good guys sometimes, but other times they just stand around and watch. Until the end of the film, then they are willing to kill the good guys again. We need to drag this out for a long time because our film is going to be really long and really slow and have as little action as possible until the last 20 minutes. This will make a great western."I could go on, but the point is made. A film with this many negatives simply cannot be great, despite what others might say. Rio Bravo is pretty weak all things considered. When I am in the mood for a western, I will never, EVER think of watching this again.6/10. Extremely slow-burn of an 'action' film that is little more than mediocre or average. Multiple negatives that cannot be ignored saddle it with -4 stars off the top.Would I watch again (Y/N)?: As I mentioned above, not very likely. I would watch 'The Magnificent Seven' 100 times straight before I watched Rio Bravo again.

Dean Martin should have gotten an award for his part in this film. I like how the two team up to fight the bad guys, you can see there's a real friendship here. A bit slow in parts but some good action scenes. My only disappointment was John Wayne didn't take on John Russell, he's a big man, a bit taller than Wayne. That would have been quite a fight to see.

reviews.review_title: Great Western made greater by self-deprecating humor
reviews.content: John Wayne famously said that the events depicted in HIGH NOON (US 1952) could never have happened in a US town, and in 1959 he jumped at the chance to do a Western with Howard Hawks showing how the people of a town under siege do not abandon their lawman.I happen to believe that the events in HIGH NOON could have happened anywhere in the world. In addition, I have never rated John Wayne a good actor, but in this film he fares better than usual. He's still the ever dominant macho, he gets the beautful girl in the end, but this time he has some respect for the three souls helping him out of a tough situation: Dean Martin, Walter Brennan and Ricky Nelson.Dean Martin, also a limited actor, posts his best performance ever in this film. He plays a drunkard, and a has-been pistol wizard on the comeback trail by containing his booze intake, and taking on the role of deputy sheriff.Ricky Nelson embodies the growing importance of youth in the movies in the 1950s - he actually has the temerity to stand up to Wayne and earns the latter's respect in the process!Angie Dickinson, then in the middle of affairs with the Kennedy brothers, is beautiful beyond words. I don't think any man could ignore such beauty, especially when she is in her undergarments at the end of the movie.But it is the wonderful Walter Brennan who steals the show as Stumpy, a cripple with a squeaky voice, and a spirited hoot of a laugh. Brennan is, of course, the only actor to have won three supporting actor Oscars so far (Daniel Day-Lewis won three Best Actor Oscars, Jack Nicholson two Best Actor and one Supporting Actor Oscars).Hawks' direction is fantastic, as is the photography.The reason I do not give RIO BRAVO 10/10 is the script. It is impossible to believe that Wayne, Nelson and Martin can walk around so carelessly in a town supposedly under siege from Burdette, a criminal seeking to remove his brother from jail, together with his band of henchmen. And that finale with Wayne and Martin shooting sticks of dynamite in the air really made me suspend all my disbelief, fun as it was to watch...In the final analysis, RIO BRAVO is good fun, and its self-deprecating humor is its loftiest quality, along with a terrific soundtrack, the cherry of which is the duet by Martin and Nelson - both great singers, then at the top of their considerable crooning powers.Definitely must-see if you like Westerns.

reviews.review_title: The Rollin' Rio Bravo Rolls Along, and Along, and Along...
reviews.content: The Wikipedia entry for this film declares it a masterpiece. It's certainly a classic: Howard Hawks directed, John Wayne starred, Dmitri Tiomkin wrote the music, and Leigh Brackett (The Big Sleep) wrote the script. It delivers a classic Western scenario: a sheriff and his sidekicks facing down a town full of villainous henchmen while they await the arrival of a federal marshal. Quentin Tarrantino claims it's his favorite movie; John Carpenter likes it too, and his "Assault on Precinct 13" is just one of the films influenced by "Rio Bravo".John Wayne stars as the sheriff, John T. Chance, and his trusty Winchester costars. There's not much that can rile Chance, perhaps because Wayne had reached a point in his career when he wasn't expected to act. Dean Martin plays Dude (not THE Dude), a recovering drunkard, crooner, and former deputy. Ricky Nelson, who takes his emotive cues from Wayne, plays a young gunslinger (perhaps descended from Cherry Valance of "Red River") along for the ride. Walter Brennan plays himself, and Angie Dickenson plays a neurotic young woman who falls for Chance.There are occasional gunfights, and an explosive climax, most of which are incidental to the plot. The movie is so relaxed in its pacing, and the lead performances are so restrained, that there is hardly any real suspense or tension. The bad guys who pop up now and then fail to threaten our heroes, and they are quickly despatched. The main villain doesn't make much of an impact. On its surface, "Rio Bravo" is hardly comparable to other Western Classics like "The Gunfighter" or "High Noon". What makes the movie stand out, and perhaps what gives it classic status, is the easy rapport of its characters and the bantering dialogue that was Hawks' trademark. It was apparently a political response to "High Noon" -- a similar story told the "right" way -- but the movie is so chilled out that it's almost impossible to read any sort of political subtext into it. It's just a fun movie.

reviews.review_title: Always Bigger than life, John Wayne at his finest here.
reviews.content: Director Howard Hawks was one of those directors that worked well with John Wayne, and was far better than Hollywood ever gave him credit for. By Hawks' own feeling, he did a better job with "El Dorado," a later remake of this film, but this was very much quintessential Hawks and Wayne at their best. It also began to set the habit of John Wayne using popular young entertainers in their early acting roles, as well as beginning to build the second tier of his stable of screen regulars. Dean Martin is excellent as the recovering drunk "Dude." You really feel his struggle to get over his alcoholism in the course of this film. And Walter Brennan as "Stumpy" was as always great. Another excellent actor in this film, aside from Ward Bond, a regular in 22 of John Wayne's films (this was their final parring) was John Russell as Nathan Burdette. Russell would later be seen in Clint Eastwood's film "Pale Rider" in 1984. And finally is Claude Akins, who just makes you hate him in this picture. As westerns go, this is often cited as one of the very best. Also a good beginning for the career of Angie Dickinson.

A perfect "hangout" movie. The story moves along slowly but the time we spend with the characters bring out a richness otherwise missed. Classic performces by the cast. Great dialogue. Great score. Great western.

When people talk about this movie they say that it is a great western. Of course but if you think twice this movie has nothing to do with westerns. Where are the fights or even the Indians ? Yes, there is a Sherif, there is the good and the evil but are you sure the Sherif is really good ? Also this movie is about waiting, maybe the greatest film about waiting. Nothing happens. The bads wait for an opportunity, the goods wait for the bads. The music is still playing. The prisoner waits for what the others are waiting on both sides. That is what is so fascinating in Hawk's movie : spectators wait with actors. They do not get borred because they know something's gonna happen. But it never happens... until the very last scene. And finally, you have waited, listening to the wonderful Dickinson's voice, seeing an alcoholic trying to escape from his condition and an old sherif falling in love. Waiting, waintin, wainting...

reviews.review_title: The American Western the way it ought to be done
reviews.content: I had not seen El Dorado for several years but I had seen and enjoyed The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance, The Alamo, and El Dorado's template, Rio Bravo several times. In a very concrete sense these are all the same movies, and could well be considered to be the godfather of the series, Deadwood. All the films include a very specific use of a broken down alcoholic, apparently not an unusual feature of the real Wild West, usually a good guy, or like in Liberty Valance, Lee Marvin, a quintessential bad guy, or as in the Alamo, well they were all drunks there apparently. John Wayne, a fine if underrated actor, of course sets the pace in all these films, even when surrounded by such excellent actors like Jimmy Stewart, Richard Widmark,Lee Marvin, Ed Asner, Woody Strode, Dean Martin, Robert Mitchum, and Walter Brennan. These movies were morality plays in the finest sense of that genre. We all know that the good gunfighters, led by Big John, will save the day, except at the Alamo where only honor was won, and they will save the day against insurmountable, almost unbelievable odds, but the action and the acting is so extraordinarily convincing that we suspend our cynicism and eagerly and breathlessly follow the action. Unfortunately, the bad gunfighters, and their leaders, are all too one dimensional, so thoroughly evil that the viewer practically prays for their demise. But except in the case of Lee Marvin's portrayal of Liberty Valance, even Ed Asner, or Claude Akins, or Santa Anna had some good qualities, or were at least fighting for a cause of some sort. It might have been more interesting, at least, to show these men as characters and not just cardboard cutouts. In the end, however, all these movies stand out from the many badly done and sadly done westerns were made around the same time. My personal belief is that John Wayne is the main reason. His drawl, his understated and yet strong, manly, and courteous character, and his exemplary behavior both on and off the screen is what made and makes him an enduring role model, and real Hollywood star, even now in our jaded and tawdry times.

I have read a number of reviews of Rio Bravo, but one thing that has not been evaluated is the performance of Angie Dickinson ( Feathers)., who reminds me of Lauren Bacall ( even the voice) in this movie. I think she ( along with Walter Brennan as Stumpy) steals the picture. Here is something;':. It is a fact about John Wayne, that after he became a star, very few women got the best of him: They were Claudette Colbert, Gail Russell, Jean Arthur, Capucine, Elsa Martinelli and Angie. Feathers wins over John T. Chance ( Wayne) by proving him wrong when he thinks she is a card cheat, and by doing what is necessary for him. How: Sleeping in a chair outside his door so he can sleep and she was going to take on gunmen holding him hostage until Colorado ( Ricky Nelson) had her throw out a flower pot to distract them. It was her willingness to go save Chance that inspired Colorado. Spoilers ahead: The final scene with her in tights was classic, with Chance saying "He will arrest her" if she goes out in public and finally admits that he will be the only one to see her in the tights. Her response was about making him talk as she said "You will have to." She knew then they were getting married. It is interesting that of all the women on that list the only one who changed him more was Russell in 'Angel And The Bad Man' I know everyone in Rio Bravo is great ( especially Brennan), and it is an easy 10/10 classic but watch the scenes with Feathers they are the best in the movie.

reviews.review_title: A Movie That Invites Many Comparisons
reviews.content: It is almost impossible to talk about this movie without talking about other movies as well. First, there are the comparisons to other movies previously directed or produced by Howard Hawks, such as "To Have and Have Not" (1944) and "The Thing from Another World" (1951); as well as two of his subsequent Westerns, "El Dorado" (1966) and "Rio Lobo" (1970), each of which also stars John Wayne.Then there is "High Noon" (1952), which Hawks disliked so much on account of the way Marshall Kane (Gary Cooper) goes around asking ordinary citizens for help and finally has to be saved by his Quaker wife that he made "Rio Bravo" in response, in which Sheriff Chance only wants professionals to help him. But whereas "High Noon" is grim, "Rio Bravo" is lighthearted, with many scenes played for laughs, and with a scene in which the good guys sing a couple of cute songs. Had Hawks not explicitly made the comparison of his movie to "High Noon," I would never have noticed, for the plot is quite different as well.Then there is "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence" (1962), directed by John Ford, who apparently did not approve of what happened in "Rio Bravo." In "Rio Bravo," the humiliating spittoon scene in the beginning leads to someone getting shot; in "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence," when Valence (Lee Marvin) trips Stoddard (James Stewart), which leads to a confrontation with Doniphon (John Wayne), Stoddard defuses the situation and nothing bad happens.Then there is "Assault on Precinct 13" (1976), which has a similar story, although it is not a western.Then there is "A Fistful of Dollars" (1964). Director Sergio Leone told composer Ennio Morricone that he wanted the music in his movie to be like the "Deguello" played in "Rio Bravo."That much I learned from reading reviews of film critics. But one comparison that occurs to me is "North to Alaska" (1960), also starring John Wayne, but, more importantly, starring Fabian. Fabian is a rock 'n' roll singer like Ricky Nelson, but a much better actor. I would have preferred to have him cast as Colorado in "Rio Bravo," and he could have sung along with Dean Martin.Another performance in the movie that I did not care for was that of Angie Dickenson as Feathers. If "Rio Bravo" were the only movie I had ever seen her in, I would think she was a bad actress. But her acting in other movies is fine, so the fault must be with the role that was handed to her. It comes across as forced and artificial. In fact, now that I think about it, maybe Ricky Nelson was not to blame for his performance as Colorado either.Despite these weak performances, and despite a weak plot that does not always make sense, it nevertheless all adds up to a pretty good movie. It's not as good as "High Noon" though.

Hawks' anti-HIGH NOON western has interesting intention, but is terribly dated for its slow-moving tempo.We see lots of Wayne entering the hotel, walking up the stairs, marching in the hallway, knocking on the door, finally going into Angie's room to have little quarrels, not to mention how Hawks shows us how Wayne exits the hotel. It's easy to cut off 20 minutes footage and tighten the whole structure. What happened to the Hawks that made fast-moving comedy HIS GIRL FRIDAY (1940)? Apparently he was getting old and tired when making this movie.Wayne is in his usual bossy style; Martin good as alcoholic deputy sheriff; Brennan terrific as Wayne's side-kick; Ricky Nelson seems out of place as experienced gunslinger; Dickinson's role didn't help her career too much.
Good but pretty underwhelming in the totality of westerns

reviews.review_title: My Rifle, My Pony, and Me
reviews.content: This movie moves as slow as molasses, and it suits me just fine! The sheriff has a man in jail, and the man's brother and their "associates" want him out. It's an old west standoff! Complete with "El Degüello" playing in the background! Walter Brennan is hilarious as Stumpy, and his chemistry with John Wayne is dang near perfect! Angie Dickinson is gorgeous, but her love story was pretty weak, though no fault of hers. The only other weakness in the film is Ricky Nelson, and he is pretty bad. But the film overcomes him, and it is a nice, slow trip through the wild ol' west. With just "my rifle, my pony, and me"!

Superb in every way.I had no idea I'd love the duo of John Wayne and Dean Martin so much. What a pair.And Walter Brennan (Stumpy), who I'd only known as the grandpa on The Real McCoys, was just hilarious.This one's a classic for a reason.

The Duke and Dean Martin (who plays a hung-over drunkard) have to wait six days for the US Federal Marshal to arrive to collect a murderer while the baddies (led by the murderer's brother) essentially lay siege to the town  The character of Stumpy is great fun  as is Carlos (a sort of Mexican version of Manuel from Fawlty Towers!). Things move quite slowly and gunshots often happen off screen and reactions seem slow compared with later spaghetti westerns  however the film starts off well and includes a cold-blooded murder in the first few minutes (which was quite unexpected and brutal) – this then forms the basis of the whole film. There's a great scene where the sheriff and his deputy enter a saloon of baddies ... The ending is preceded by a couple of songs which fit reasonably well into the film – then there's quite a tense 'exchange' scene before the ending when the Duke gets the girl. All clean wholesome fun – and none of the good guys get killed ... Very good enjoyable standard big screen western – ideal for a rainy Sunday matinée.

Rio Bravo is a brilliant old-style western, with John Wayne effectively playing himself as usual, but doing it with panache as ever.
